newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy to unveil tough budget in dash for EMU.
newsitem.headline: Italy to unveil tough budget in dash for EMU.

text.p: Italy's government said on Thursday it was ready to unveil a 50 trillion lire 1997 budget ($32.9 billion) in a bid to join a single European currency after a key hard-left ally softened opposition to welfare cuts.

Foreign Trade Minister August Fantozzi told reporters after a summit meeting of party leaders in the centre-left coalition led by Prime Minister Romano Prodi that the budget would cut Italy's deficit to gross domestic (GDP) ratio to three percent.
The planned budget, which will include a special "Euro-tax," is well in excess of the 32.4 trillion lire the government had originally intended to slash from the public sector deficit.
Achievement of the three percent deficit target would put Italy on course to join an advance party of countries setting up a single European currency in 1999, Fantozzi said.
"The numbers to get into Europe are there and they will take us to three percent," Fantozzi said. "They will allow us to be with the other countries from the start."
The cabinet is due to approve the budget on Friday before submitting it to parliament, which must pass it into law by the end of December.

The Euro-tax would raise between 10 and 12 trillion lire next year while two trillion lire in savings would come through streamlining pensions spending and a further two trillion lire from savings on healthcare, a government source said.
The government has not said where the Euro-tax would fall but newspapers have reported that it would be in the form of a once-off increase in income tax.

Financial markets, which have been electrified by the prospect of a tough budget, greeted the announcement with a fresh burst of euphoria. The lira rose to 994.4 against the mark, its highest level for more than two years, while bond prices surged to new record highs.

Fausto Bertinotti, leader of the hard-left Communist Refoundation party, who was bitterly opposed to Treasury plans to cut health and pensions spending, said after meeting Prodi that budget talks with government allies had made progress.
"Even if there continue to be problems, we have made a significant step forward," Bertinotti told reporters.
"Naturally until we have crossed the finishing line, and we will cross the finishing line tomorrow evening with the presentation of the budget, there will continue to be problems," said Bertinotti.
Prodi's government, appointed in May, relies on Communist Refoundation for its majority in the lower house of parliament.

Right-wing opposition leaders said that Prodi had caved in to pressure from the hard left. "You cannot go into Europe with accounting tricks," said Maurizio Gasparri, a senior member of the post-fascist National Alliance.

"Now we want to see the text because the impression is that it's a cosmetic agreement while it is clear that we are faced with a (government) majority which is more than ever blackmailed by Bertinotti," he said.

The planned Euro tax may receive a hostile reception in a country which already bears one of Europe's steepest tax burdens. A Datamedia poll conducted on Wednesday showed 56.4 percent of a sample of 1,002 Italians were not prepared to pay.

One economist voiced concern at the possible impact of fiscal entrenchment on an already faltering economy. "One has to be extremely concerned as to the impact of this on the economy. It could be very bad for growth," said Darren Williams, a London-based economist with Swiss bank UBS.
